Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Puerto Rico Honey Bee and Evolution of Invasive Organisms on Islands; August 13-15, 2019; San Juan, Puerto Rico
Award.AbstractNarration:
Honey bees are among the most successful invasive organisms worldwide, both on and off islands. They play a key role as pollinators in agricultural systems worldwide, but are also threatened by human activities. This award supports the first conference to examine one strain of non-native honey bee, the Puerto Rico Gentle Africanized honey bee, through the lens of invasion biology and island biogeography. The conference is timely for two reasons. First, the introduction and radiation of invasive organisms, and threats to honey bee health, continue unabated. Second, invasive organisms - and honey bees in particular - have a critical impact on global food security. In this conference, researchers will communicate new findings that aim to stimulate their research and that of their students and interact directly with stakeholders who can apply basic research findings to improve management decisions. The new research directions and improved management decisions are expected to translate into economic benefits for a much-challenged Puerto Rico island economy. Additionally, because the invited participants include a diverse set of student participants from the University of Puerto Rico, this conference has the potential to broaden participation in STEM.

The amount and type of data available for honey bees, including the Puerto Rico Gentle Africanized honey bee, are unparalleled. However, bee researchers do not use an invasive biology perspective, and invasive biology studies typically do not examine the honey bee as a model. The adaptation of Africanized honey bees to the island of Puerto Rico is an example of the changes that can occur to invasive organisms and their ecosystem during island colonization. The invasion process impacts the invading as well as the resident species and the ecosystem in which they navigate. One of the advantages of studying island populations is that such adaptive processes are accelerated. Moreover, adaptive processes may show similar patterns across species and as such, data from island populations can be particularly useful to develop and test models of invasion biology. This three-day conference will develop an integrative analysis approach to honey bee invasions using various types of data generated by different research areas and approaches to invasion biology. These include genomics, morphology, behavior and ecology. On the first day, all participants will give presentations. For the second day, attendees will visit field sites to observe the honey bee population established on the island of Puerto Rico. On the third day, attendees will form breakout groups for round table discussions leading to a strategic plan on research directions, resources, and policy advice on bees and other invasive organisms on islands.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the first conference to examine the Puerto Rico Gentle Africanized honey bee (PRG Bee) population within the context of invasion biology and island biogeography. The introduction and radiation of invasive organisms as well as threats to honey bee health continue unabated. Due to the far-reaching negative effects of invasive organisms and the critical global importance of honey bees on human food security this conference and its associated workshop was timely and of consequence in furthering research and collaborations in these areas of investigation.   In this conference researchers communicated new findings in 36 talks that resulted in: 1) Advancement of their research and that of their students; 2) A rare opportunity for scientists to interact with stakeholders who learned of basic research findings for the application towards the improvement of management decisions; 3) The new research directions and improved management decisions are expected to translate into economic benefits for a challenged Puerto Rico island economy.

Honey bees represent the most successful invasive organisms on and off islands, and the amount and type of data available for this organism are unparalleled. This workshop invited invasive biology researchers and honey bee biologists and stakeholders to use an invasive biology perspective with the honey bee as a model.

The adaptation of Africanized honey bees (AHB) to the island of Puerto Rico is an example of changes that can occur to invasive organisms and their ecosystem during island colonization. The invasive process impacts the invading as well as resident species and the ecosystem in which they navigate. Due to their unique aspects, adaptive processes on islands are usually accelerated. As such, islands are a rich resource for the experimental testing of evolutionary hypotheses. Moreover, adaptive processes may show similar patterns across species, and data from island populations can be particularly useful to develop and test models of invasion biology.

The 3-day workshop developed an integrative analysis approach using various types of data generated by workers from different research areas and approaches to invasion biology.  These included genomics, morphology, behavior and ecology. After the workshop researchers and stake holders remained in contact and organized a special issue in the journal Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, titled: ?Adaptation of Invasive Species to Islands and the Puerto Rican Honey Bee?.  This special issue includes articles extending from reviews of the status of Africanized bees to the interaction of honey bees and other pollinators, as well as a policy article on honey bee movement into the US.  Currently 11 articles have been published with a combined number of 21,054 views and 4 additional articles are in print.

During the Covid-19 shutdown, when research opportunities for students and researchers were limited, the organizers amplified the positive impact of the workshop by arranging an additional workshop of online genomic data analysis.  This interactive workshop resulted in graduate, undergraduate students and researchers in the field of invasive biology being able to gain expertise in bioinformatics required for their research projects. This experience in turn allowed students to continue to progress in their academic requirements despite Covid-19 pandemic limitations.  As a result one of the student workshop participants, Carlos Ortiz Alvarado, was able to defend his Ph.D. thesis in a timely manner on the 30th of June 2021.

The broader impacts of this project have been three fold. First, the project provided an opportunity for international and national members of the honey bee and broader invasive ecology scientists communities to present research and discuss factors influencing selection in invasive populations such as honey bees; Second, the project enabled the sharing of, the substantial, currently available work on the Puerto Rico and Africanized honey bees, which encompasses genetic, behavioral, and population diversity. The invasion biology approach and tools now permit in depth investigations of the influence of island biogeography and extreme weather events on the population of the Puerto Rico honey bee in particular, as well as other isolated populations; Third, the project resulted in outlining a strategic plan to protect the honey bee population of the island of Puerto Rico as a valuable natural resource. The honey bee population in Puerto Rico can be harnessed to stimulate and improve the economic growth of Puerto Rico and at the same time aid in the response to the pollinator crisis in the U.S.A. and the world.
